text:
Provides legal framework for arbitration, enforcement of awards, and interim measures. [Summary]
Encourages out-of-court dispute resolution via arbitration with enforcement mechanisms.

Willful damage to property and arson are punishable under IPC’s mischief and related sections. [Summary]
Covers property damage offences and related penalties.

Banking frauds and offences have specific criminal sanctions and regulatory remedies. [Summary]
Covers bank fraud and instrument misuse.

Local municipal laws regulate construction, permits, and penalties for illegal construction. [Summary]
Local compliance and remedy mechanisms for building law violations.

Insider trading and securities fraud are regulated; penalties under SEBI and other statutes apply. [Summary]
Regulation of insider trading under securities laws; corporate governance rules.

A consumer complaint may be filed regarding:
(a) defective goods,
(b) deficient services,
(c) unfair trade practices,
(d) overcharging,
(e) misleading advertisements. Complaints may be filed online via the National Consumer Helpline.

Procedures for returning defective goods and claiming refunds under consumer laws. [Summary]
Consumer rights for defective product remedies.

Regulates false advertising and unfair trade practices with penalties. [Summary]
Consumer protection against misrepresentation in trade.
A manufacturer, seller, or service provider is liable for harm caused by defective products, manufacturing defects, design defects, or failure to warn consumers.

Consumers can file complaints in District, State, or National Commissions for defective goods and unfair trade practices. [Summary]
Explains consumer complaints and compensation mechanisms.

Complaints about online services, defamation via platforms, and related consumer issues can be filed with appropriate commissions; separate criminal remedy may apply. [Summary]
Victims may have regulatory/consumer options in addition to criminal remedies.

Consumers have the following rights:
1. Right to Safety — protection against hazardous goods/services. 2. Right to Information — correct details about product quality, quantity, price, etc. 3. Right to Choose — access to a variety of goods/services at competitive prices.
4. Right to be Heard — consumer grievances must be addressed. 5. Right to Redressal — compensation for defective goods or deficient services. 6. Right to Consumer Education.
Complaints may be filed at District, State, or National Commissions depending on claim value.

Time limits and procedures for consumer claims, including warranty claims. [Summary]
Covers timebars and remedies at consumer commissions.

"Fraud" includes:
(a) suggestion of untrue facts,
(b) active concealment,
(c) promise made without intention to perform,
(d) any act fitted to deceive. A contract induced by fraud is voidable.

Procedure and principles for granting bail including factors courts consider. [Summary]
Explains different bail types and judicial considerations.

Every information relating to a cognizable offence, if given orally to an officer in charge of a police station, shall be reduced to writing and read over to the informant. A copy of the FIR must be provided free of cost.
Any officer in charge of a police station may investigate any cognizable case without order of a Magistrate. The Magistrate may also order investigation under this section.

A police officer may, without the order of a Magistrate, investigate any cognizable case. [Summary]
Police powers to investigate cognizable offenses.

When investigation cannot be completed within 24 hours, the accused may be forwarded to a Magistrate who may authorize detention for:
• up to 15 days in police custody,
• up to 90 days for serious offences,
• up to 60 days for other offences.

A Magistrate may take cognizance of an offence upon:
(a) receiving a complaint,
(b) a police report,
(c) information from any person,
(d) upon his own knowledge.
A Magistrate taking cognizance of an offence on complaint shall examine the complainant and the witnesses upon oath, and the substance of such examination shall be recorded.
A Magistrate may postpone issue of process and inquire into the case or direct a police investigation to determine if there is sufficient ground to proceed.
If the Magistrate finds sufficient grounds to proceed, they shall issue summons or warrant to the accused.
Certain offences may be compounded (settled) by the victim, such as simple hurt, defamation, trespass, and adultery. Some require court permission.

Any police officer may, without an order from a Magistrate and without a warrant, arrest any person:
(a) who has committed a cognizable offence,
(b) who is in possession of stolen property,
(c) who obstructs a police officer in the execution of duty,
(d) who is a proclaimed offender,
(e) who commits a cognizable offence in the presence of the officer,
(f) against whom credible information exists of involvement in a cognizable offence. Arrest should be made only when necessary and with recorded reasons.

Circumstances where police may arrest without warrant, and duties post-arrest. [Summary]
When police can arrest without a warrant and required procedural safeguards.

When any person has reason to believe that they may be arrested on accusation of a non-bailable offence, they may apply to the High Court or Court of Session for anticipatory bail. The Court may grant interim protection and impose conditions such as:
(a) the person shall make themselves available for interrogation,
(b) shall not make threats or inducements to any person,
(c) shall not leave India without court permission.

Procedure for producing arrested persons before Magistrate and remand decisions. [Summary]
Describes custody and remand timelines and magistrate’s role.

Phishing, identity theft, unauthorized access and financial cybercrimes are prosecutable under IT Act and IPC. [Summary]
Common cybercrime types and applicable laws for prosecution.

Death of a woman within seven years of marriage due to dowry-related cruelty is a distinct offence with severe punishment. [Summary]
Dowry death has specific presumption of dowry-related cruelty and high penalties.

Giving or taking dowry is prohibited; demands and harassment related to dowry are punishable. [Summary]
Covers dowry demands and related criminal and civil remedies.

"Domestic violence" includes:
(a) physical abuse — causing bodily pain or harm,
(b) sexual abuse — any conduct of a sexual nature that abuses, humiliates, or degrades,
(c) verbal and emotional abuse — insults, humiliation, name-calling, threats,
(d) economic abuse — deprivation of financial resources, disposal of assets without consent, restricting access to household necessities. The Act provides protection orders, residence orders, monetary relief, custody orders, and compensation.

title_meta: Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act — Protection Orders
text:
A Protection Order may prohibit the respondent from:
(a) committing domestic violence,
(b) entering the victim’s residence,
(c) attempting to communicate,
(d) alienating assets,
(e) causing violence to dependents.

The Magistrate may:
(a) restrain the respondent from dispossessing the victim,
(b) direct the respondent to remove themselves from the shared household,
(c) restrain the respondent from entering certain portions of the home,
(d) secure alternate accommodation for the victim.

Corrupt practices, illegal conduct in elections and associated penalties. [Summary]
Covers offences around elections and corrupt practices.

Framework for electricity supply, licensing, and consumer grievance redressal. [Summary]
Regulatory structure for power distribution and consumer rights.

Employers must pay minimum wages and overtime where applicable; enforcement mechanisms exist. [Summary]
Worker rights for pay and overtime, and enforcement options.

Pollution control, regulatory powers and penalties for breaches under environmental law. [Summary]
Covers penalties and remedial orders for environmental harm.
A confession made by an accused is irrelevant if it appears to the Court to have been caused by inducement, threat, or promise from a person in authority.
Statements made by a person as to the cause of their death, or as to circumstances of the transaction resulting in their death, are relevant even if the person is dead.
Electronic records are admissible as evidence if accompanied by a certificate under Section 65B(4) stating the manner of production, device details, and assurance of integrity.

Disciplines for collecting, preserving and presenting forensic evidence in courts. [Summary]
Importance of chain-of-custody for admissible forensic evidence.

Grounds for divorce vary by personal law; cruelty, adultery, desertion are common grounds. [Summary]
Overview of divorce grounds and civil remedies depending on personal law.

Regulatory framework for food safety, licensing, and penalties for adulteration. [Summary]
Enforcement mechanisms for food safety violations.

Regulates foreign exchange dealings and penalties for contravention. [Summary]
Controls on foreign exchange transactions and penalties for violations.

GST return filing timelines and penalties for non-compliance. [Summary]
Explains reporting obligations under GST law.

Outlines penalties for late filing, evasion, and fraudulent claims. [Summary]
Consequences for non-compliance with GST obligations.
The Court may appoint a guardian when it is satisfied that it is necessary for the welfare of a minor.

Speech that incites communal hatred or violence can be prosecuted under various provisions. [Summary]
Prohibits incitement to violence and communal discord.
Either spouse may seek judicial separation on grounds of cruelty, desertion, adultery, or other grounds similar to divorce.

A marriage may be dissolved by a decree of divorce on grounds such as:
(a) cruelty,
(b) desertion for a continuous period of not less than two years,
(c) adultery,
(d) conversion to another religion,
(e) incurable mental disorder,
(f) venereal disease,
(g) renunciation of the world,
(h) not heard of as alive for seven years. Either spouse may file for divorce based on these grounds.
The Court may pass interim or final orders regarding custody, maintenance, and education of minor children during marriage or divorce proceedings.

Commissions receive complaints of human rights violations and recommend remedies. [Summary]
Non-judicial redressal forums for rights violations.

Penalties and prosecution provisions for tax evasion and fraud. [Summary]
Covers penalties and criminal liability for tax offences.

Policy terms, claims process, and dispute resolution for insurance claims. [Summary]
Explains claims filing and grievance redressal mechanisms.

Whoever is a party to a criminal conspiracy to commit an offense shall be punished as a conspirator. [Summary]
Criminal conspiracy covers agreements to commit offenses; conspirators can be punished even if the planned offense was not completed.
Whoever is a party to a criminal conspiracy shall be punished with imprisonment up to six months, or more depending on the offence conspired.

An assembly of five or more persons whose common object is to commit an offense, resist the execution of law, or commit mischief, etc. is an unlawful assembly. [Summary]
Defines unlawful assembly and when group action is criminal.

When force or violence is used by an unlawful assembly in prosecution of common object, members are guilty of rioting. [Summary]
Rioting describes violent acts by groups; punishments vary with severity.

Rioting while being armed with deadly weapon increases punishment. [Summary]
Being armed during rioting attracts higher penalties.
Giving false information to a public servant to cause them to use their authority to injure or annoy another person is punishable with imprisonment up to six months or fine.
Falsely charging a person with an offence knowing that there is no lawful ground is punishable with imprisonment up to two years, or up to seven years if the charge is grave.

The sale or distribution of obscene material (including electronic distribution) is prohibited and punishable. [Summary]
Obscene publications distributed online can be prosecuted under IPC.

Acts intended to insult religious feelings of any class are punishable. [Summary]
Prohibits actions that outrage religious feelings.

Deliberate and malicious acts intended to outrage religious feelings of any class by insulting its religion or beliefs shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years, or with fine, or with both.

Deliberate and malicious acts intended to outrage religious feelings are punished. [Summary]
Targets deliberate attacks on religious harmony.
Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine. [Summary]
Defines punishment for murder and severity of sentences.

Punishment for culpable homicide that does not amount to murder depends on intent and circumstances. [Summary]
Lesser degree of culpable homicide with reduced punishment compared to murder.

Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge and under such circumstances that, if they caused death, they would be guilty of murder, shall be punished with imprisonment up to ten years, and also liable to fine.

Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge and under such circumstances that, if they caused death, they would be guilty of murder, is guilty of attempt to murder. [Summary]
Attempted murder carries heavy imprisonment even if death did not occur.
Whoever voluntarily causes hurt shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.
Whoever voluntarily causes hurt by means of any dangerous weapon or instrument shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
When a criminal act is done by several persons in furtherance of the common intention of all, each of such persons is liable as if they alone committed the act.

Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any woman, intending to outrage or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby outrage her modesty, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than one year but which may extend to five years, and shall also be liable to fine.

Sexual harassment includes:
(a) unwelcome physical contact,
(b) demand for sexual favours,
(c) showing pornography,
(d) sexually coloured remarks. Punishable with imprisonment up to three years or fine.

Sexual harassment includes unwelcome physical contact, advances, or remarks; in some contexts online sexual harassment may be covered. [Summary]
Online sexual harassment can be treated as sexual harassment depending on facts.

Capturing or sharing private acts or images without consent is punishable. [Summary]
Addresses non-consensual photography and image dissemination.

Capturing a person’s private acts or sharing private images without consent is punishable. [Summary]
Non-consensual image-sharing or voyeurism attracts criminal penalties.

Whoever follows a woman and monitors the use by a woman of the internet, email or any other form of electronic communication, commits the offense of stalking. [Summary]
Stalking (including electronic monitoring) is a punishable offense.

A man is said to commit rape if he has sexual intercourse with a woman under circumstances including:
(a) against her will,
(b) without her consent,
(c) with consent obtained by fear or fraud,
(d) with consent when she is intoxicated,
(e) with consent given under a mistaken identity,
(f) with or without her consent when she is under 18 years of age.
Punishment for rape shall not be less than ten years and may extend to life imprisonment, along with fine, considering physical and mental trauma inflicted on the victim.

Rape is punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a specified minimum term and may extend to life imprisonment under certain circumstances. [Summary]
Defines punishment for rape and aggravating factors.
Whoever commits theft shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
Whoever commits criminal breach of trust shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years, or with fine, or with both.
Whoever cheats and dishonestly induces the person deceived to deliver any property shall be punished with imprisonment up to seven years and shall also be liable to fine.

Whoever cheats and dishonestly induces the person deceived to deliver property shall be punished with imprisonment and fine. [Summary]
Defines cheating and criminal consequences for fraudulent inducement.

Whoever, being the husband or the relative of the husband of a woman, subjects such woman to cruelty shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years and shall also be liable to fine. Explanation — For the purpose of this section, "cruelty" means:
(a) any willful conduct likely to drive the woman to commit suicide or cause grave injury; or
(b) harassment with a view to coercing her or her relatives to meet unlawful demands for dowry.

Subjecting a married woman to cruelty that may drive her to suicide or cause grave injury is punishable. [Summary]
Domestic cruelty by husband/relatives is a non-bailable offence in many cases.

Summary:
Whoever, by words spoken or written, signs, visible representations, or publications harms the reputation of a person is said to commit defamation. Exception:
Certain acts like truth for public good, expressing opinions in good faith, and comments on public conduct are not defamation. Source: https://www.indiacode.nic.in/

title_meta: Title: IPC Section 500 — Punishment for defamation
text:
Summary:
Defamation is punishable with simple imprisonment which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both. Source: https://www.indiacode.nic.in/

Whoever defames another shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both. [Summary]
Punishment for defamation may include imprisonment up to two years, fine, or both.

Whoever threatens another with injury to person, reputation or property, or to cause alarm, is guilty of criminal intimidation. [Summary]
Threats of harm to person or reputation are punishable.

Whoever intentionally insults, and thereby gives provocation to any person, intending or knowing it to be likely that such provocation will cause him to break the public peace, is punishable. [Summary]
Intentional insults that provoke breach of the peace are punishable.

Statements made with intent to cause fear or alarm among public, or incite violence, may be punished under clause (2). [Summary]
Social media posts that incite public disorder or fear may fall under this provision.

Statements likely to cause fear, alarm, or enmity among communities are punishable. [Summary]
Applies to statements (including online) that can incite public disorder.

Whoever makes, publishes, or circulates any statement, rumor or report with intent to cause, or which is likely to cause, any officer, soldier, sailor or airman to mutiny or disorderly conduct, or to encourage animosity among communities, shall be punished. [Summary]
Publishing certain statements that cause public alarm, enmity, or danger is punishable.

Whoever commits criminal intimidation is punishable with imprisonment or fine. [Summary]
Specifies punishments for intimidation and threatening acts.

title_meta: Title: IPC Section 507 — Criminal intimidation by anonymous communication
text:
Summary:
Whoever commits the offense of criminal intimidation by anonymous communication shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to two years. Source: https://www.indiacode.nic.in/

Various provisions address stalking and harassment; online stalking which induces fear or alarm may be covered by criminal intimidation, causing hurt, or other specific provisions. [Summary]
Online stalking/harassment can be prosecuted under stalking, intimidation, or related IPC sections depending on facts.

Whoever, intending to insult the modesty of any woman, utters any word, makes any sound, gesture, or exhibits any object with intent that it be heard or seen, shall be punished with imprisonment up to one year, or with fine, or with both.
Intentionally insulting the modesty of a woman through words, gestures, or intrusion upon her privacy is punishable with imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.

Insulting the modesty of a woman by words, gestures, or acts is an offense. [Summary]
Covers insulting behavior targeting a woman's modesty.

Whoever intends to insult the modesty of a woman by word or gesture shall be punished. [Summary]
Offensive words/gestures intended to insult a woman's modesty are punishable.

If any person, dishonestly or fraudulently, does any act referred to in Section 43 (such as unauthorized access, data modification, virus introduction), they shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years or with fine up to five lakh rupees, or both.

Whoever cheats or dishonestly induces any person by personation using a computer or network shall be punished with imprisonment or fine. [Summary]
Using electronic means to impersonate or cheat is an offense under the IT Act.

Note: Section 66A (which criminalized sending offensive messages) was struck down by the Supreme Court; however, other provisions and IPC sections remain applicable for online misuse. [Summary]
66A is no longer in force; rely on IPC/IT Act provisions currently operative.

Identity theft involving fraudulent or dishonest use of another person’s password, biometric data, or electronic signature is punishable with imprisonment up to three years and fine up to one lakh rupees.

Cheating by impersonation using a computer resource or network is punishable. [Summary]
Impersonation/fraud via digital means is an offense under IT Act.
Cheating by personation using electronic communication, including phishing or online scams, is punishable with imprisonment up to three years and fine up to one lakh rupees.

Whoever intentionally captures, publishes or transmits images of a private area of a person without consent shall be punished. [Summary]
Capturing and sharing private images without consent is an offence under IT Act.

Whoever publishes or transmits or causes to be published or transmitted in electronic form any material which is lascivious or appeals to the prurient interest, or if its effect is such as to tend to deprave and corrupt persons, shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years on first conviction, and up to five years on subsequent convictions, along with fine.

Publishing or transmitting obscene content online is punishable with imprisonment and fine. [Summary]
Regulates obscene material distributed electronically.

title_meta: Title: IT Act Section 67 — Publishing or transmitting obscene material in electronic form
text:
Summary:
Whoever publishes or transmits obscene content electronically shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years and a fine for the first conviction; and imprisonment up to five years for subsequent convictions. Source: https://www.indiacode.nic.in/

The IT Act and IPC provisions together address persistent online harassment, repeated unwanted messages, threats and cyberstalking. [Summary]
Repeated unwanted communications and harassment can be prosecuted using IT Act and IPC provisions.

Provides procedures for juveniles in conflict with law, including rehabilitation, adoption of child protection measures. [Summary]
Focuses on reformative measures for minors rather than punitive ones.
Gratuity is payable to an employee who has completed five years of continuous service upon termination, resignation, retirement, or death.
Employers must pay at least the minimum rates of wages fixed by the government. Payment must be timely and in cash or bank transfer.

Rules on timely payment of wages and permissible deductions under employment laws. [Summary]
Protects workers’ wage rights and remedies for violation.

Procedural requirements to register property transfers and remedies for disputes. [Summary]
Registration formalities and legal effect on property rights.

Eviction for non-payment of rent, use violations, and landlord remedies under relevant state laws. [Summary]
Eviction requires statutory procedure; state-specific laws apply.

Court may order maintenance for spouse/children during proceedings where necessary. [Summary]
Covers interim maintenance and court powers to protect dependent spouses.
The Court may order either spouse to pay maintenance and litigation expenses to the other spouse if they lack independent income to support themselves during court proceedings.
When either spouse withdraws from the society of the other without reasonable cause, the aggrieved party may apply for restitution of conjugal rights.

Grounds for annulment and distinctions between void and voidable marriages under personal laws. [Summary]
Explains annulment and legal consequences for parties.

Patients can seek civil remedies for negligence and compensation via courts or consumer forums. [Summary]
Medical negligence claims are civil in nature with potential compensation.

Employers must pay at least the statutory minimum wage to workers in scheduled employments. [Summary]
Defines minimum wage obligations and enforcement mechanisms.

Procedures to claim compensation for motor accident victims via Motor Accidents Claims Tribunal. [Summary]
Provides forum and procedure for accident compensation claims.

Owners must have at least third-party insurance for vehicles; compensation rules apply for accidents. [Summary]
Ensures compensation mechanisms for victims of motor accidents.
Driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs with blood alcohol exceeding 30 mg/100 ml is punishable with imprisonment up to six months or fine for first offence.

title_meta: MV Act Section 279 (IPC equivalent used with MVA)
text: Rash or negligent driving on a public way endangering human life is punishable with imprisonment up to six months or fine.

Possession, trafficking, and production of narcotic substances are severely punished under NDPS Act. [Summary]
Strict penalties for drug-related offenses; wide-ranging enforcement powers.

Drawer of cheque may face criminal liability when cheque bounces for insufficiency of funds. [Summary]
Cheque bounce can have criminal penalties and civil remedies.

Where a cheque drawn by a person for payment of any debt or other liability is returned due to insufficient funds, the drawer may be punishable. [Summary]
Cheque bounce has criminal remedies under Section 138; included for financial harassment contexts.
Dishonour of cheque due to insufficient funds is punishable with imprisonment up to two years or fine up to twice the cheque amount. The payee must issue a notice within 30 days.

Rules for partition, inheritance and succession depend on personal laws and statutes. [Summary]
Explains partition procedure and inheritance basics.
Punishment for penetrative sexual assault shall be imprisonment not less than ten years, extendable to life imprisonment, and liable to fine.
Sexual assault includes touching the vagina, penis, anus, or breast of a child, or making the child touch these parts, or doing any other act with sexual intent.

Mechanisms exist to file complaints against police misconduct; state police complaint authorities may apply. [Summary]
Options to complain about police excesses or procedural lapses.

Punishment for penetrative sexual assault with minimum imprisonment and fines as specified. [Summary]
Covers crimes involving children and strict punishments under POCSO.

title_meta: Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act Section 3
text: Sexual harassment includes unwelcome acts such as physical contact, demands for sexual favours, showing pornography, or sexually coloured remarks.

title_meta: Privacy, Data Protection & Personal Data Rules
text:
While a comprehensive Data Protection law is evolving, IT Act rules and other statutes regulate personal data handling. [Summary]
Explains current privacy protections and potential statutory remedies.

Unauthorized sharing of sensitive personal data may be actionable under IT Act rules and privacy frameworks. [Summary]
Sharing personal data without consent may violate privacy rules and IT Act provisions.

title_meta: Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act
text:
Provides civil remedies, protection orders, and maintenance for victims of domestic violence. [Summary]
Gives immediate protective relief (orders, residence rights) to victims.

Measures for reporting corruption or malpractice and protections for whistleblowers. [Summary]
Mechanisms for reporting wrongdoing and safeguards for reporters.

Guidelines exist for survivors' examination, evidence collection, and chain-of-custody for sexual assault cases. [Summary]
Procedural safeguards for survivors and admissibility of forensic evidence.
A person seeking information shall make a request in writing or electronically to the Public Information Officer, specifying the information sought. No reasons for seeking information are required.
Information must be provided within 30 days of the request. If information concerns life or liberty, it must be provided within 48 hours.
Intentionally insulting, intimidating, assaulting, or dispossessing a member of SC/ST community due to caste is punishable with imprisonment not less than six months and up to five years.

Rules for lawful termination, disciplinary hearings and remedies for wrongful dismissal. [Summary]
Procedure for fair disciplinary process and appeals in employment.

Intermediary liability rules set out takedown and safe-harbour conditions for platforms. [Summary]
Explains when platforms are protected from liability and when they must act on complaints.

Severe provisions for terrorism-related offences with special procedure; stringent bail rules. [Summary]
Covers anti-terror laws and special procedural provisions.

Basics of registration, infringement, and remedies for IP rights (trademarks, copyright). [Summary]
High-level overview of intellectual property protections and enforcement.

Traffic rules, penalties for speeding, drunk driving, and vehicle offences including license suspensions. [Summary]
Road safety offences and penalties for drivers.

Employers must provide internal complaint committees and processes to address workplace sexual harassment. [Summary]
Employer obligations and internal remedies for workplace harassment.
